Andy, thanks for pointing this issue out.  Those are interesting 
statistic=
s.  It is indeed best to avoid reevaluating an organism that 
is the same a=
s one that has come before.  10% is not terrible but it 
does mean evolutio=
n could have been even faster.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "afcarl2"=
 <a.carl@...> wrote:
>
> Investigation of redundant organisms in NEAT using=
 standard param 
> values has shown an approximate 10 percent redundancy fa=
ctor as 
follows:
> 
> Population Size: 100
> Number Outputs: 10 (i.e. 10-d=
imensional coordinate space)
> Distance Tolerance: 1.0E-6 (in non-normalize=
d coordinates)
> 
> Duplicates in Generation 1 were ignored.
> 
> "A" =3D G=
eneration Number
> "B" =3D Cum # of Redundant Organisms (i.e. less than tol=
 distance 
apart)
> "C" =3D Total Number of Organisms Evaluated
> 
> "A","B=
","C"
> 1,0,100
> 2,8,200
> 3,17,300
> 4,30,400
> 5,44,500
> 6,56,600
> 7,6=
5,700
> 8,76,800
> 9,94,900
> 10,115,1000
> 
> In instances in which the fi=
tness computational requirements are 
non-
> trivial, screening and fitness=
 substitution for redundant organisms 
is 
> justified. The issues of searc=
h space coverage and variaion with 
param 
> value changes were not address=
ed. 
> 
> ( Reference Resource: ANN: A Library for Approximate Nearest 
Nei=
ghbor 
> Searching, Mount, David M., Arya, Sunil,

~mount/ANN/ )
